docs.snippet: LEAD: Repertorio Espanol is 20 years old this summer, a milestone the company is too busy to observe and one that is unlikely to seize the attention of New York's mainstream theater world. Repertorio, which remains adamantly Castilian in tongue, tone...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Repertorio Espanol is 20 years old this summer, a milestone the company is too busy to observe and one that is unlikely to seize the attention of New York's mainstream theater world. Repertorio, which remains adamantly Castilian in tongue, tone and tune, is one of the more venerable professional repertory groups in the nation, and offers a profusion of plays, dance and musicals that would, in its native land, be at center stage in the cultural scene.

headline.main: Repertorio Espanol Goes on With el Espectaculo

docs.snippet: LEAD: In the first verdict of its kind, the Inter-American Court of Human Rights today found the Honduran Government guilty in the disappearance of a Honduran citizen in 1981.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: In the first verdict of its kind, the Inter-American Court of Human Rights today found the Honduran Government guilty in the disappearance of a Honduran citizen in 1981.

headline.main: O.A.S. Tribunal Finds Honduras Responsible for a Political Killing

docs.snippet: LEAD:  International A2-10  Secretary of State George P. Shultz and four Central American foreign ministers failed to agree on a denunciation of Nicaragua. A communique issued at the end of their meeting did not mention Nicaragua. Page A1

byline.original: By William D. Rogers; William D. Rogers was Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs in the Ford Administration

docs.snippet: LEAD: Arriving here today after a weeklong tour of Latin America, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said he was pleased with talks held in Brasilia with Brazilian leaders. The talks, held Friday, concerned Central American security and a trade...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Arriving here today after a weeklong tour of Latin America, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said he was pleased with talks held in Brasilia with Brazilian leaders. The talks, held Friday, concerned Central American security and a trade dispute between the United States and Brazil.
